question: Can I choose specific (prescribed) courses as part of the Carolina Core for my program?

question: Do all changes to a cross-listed course affect any cross-listed course(s) as well?
answer: Common Reasons Proposals are Returned from the Curricula and Courses Committee: Getting approval for distributed learning for one cross-listed course does not automatically approve cross listed courses for distributed learning delivery. Separate submissions are required for each course. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/docs/f23232.pdf)
phi: Not always. Changes to a cross-listed course's syllabus, schedule, or instructor may affect all cross-listings. However, some updates might be specific to one listing and not impact others. Always confirm with the department handling the cross-listing for clarity.

question: How do Carolina Core Overlay courses work?
answer: Carolina Core overlay courses meet two Carolina Core learning outcomes in one course. Students may apply a maximum of two overlay courses to their Carolina Core hours. All students must have a minimum of 31 hours of Carolina Core. For a list of overlay-eligible courses, visit the Carolina Core website and sort by the Overlay column in the table. Learn more with the Carolina Core Overlay Training Module (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/academicpriorities/undergradstudies/carolinacore/courses/foundational-courses.php, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bed1TZJfbhs&feature=youtu.be&t=2m55s)
phi: Carolina Core Overlay courses at USC are designed to deepen understanding of key concepts across disciplines. They enable students to complete their major requirements with fewer courses. Typically, these overlays are offered in a shorter, more intensive format and encourage cross-listed learning. For specific details, visit USC's core curriculum page or contact the Registrar's Office.
llama: The Carolina Core Overlay courses are a unique aspect of USC's core curriculum. These courses provide added depth and breadth to your education, allowing you to explore specific areas of interest. Overlays are compatible with various majors and career paths. I recommend checking the USCwebsite or speaking with an academic advisor for more detailed information!
gemini: Carolina Core Overlay courses allow you to fulfill multiple course requirements with a single class. For example, a history course could satisfy both a Carolina Core and a major requirement. It's a great way to streamline your academic plan!
mixtral: Carolina Core Overlay courses are centered around USC's core themes, offering students opportunities to explore specific topics in-depth while fulfilling general education requirements.

question: How do I know if I need a curriculum change proposal to make a change in the Bulletin?
answer: A curriculum change proposal is required when substantive changes are needed. Changes that are non-substantive include typos, grammar errors, formatting changes, and other changes that do not affect the meaning or interpretation of curricular information.
phi:
To propose a curriculum change at the University of South Carolina, you must follow these steps: 

1. Consult with your academic advisor or department chair.
2. Research and draft your proposal, considering USC's academic goals and policies.
3. Seek feedback from relevant faculty and stakeholders.
4. Submit the proposal to the Curriculum Committee via the USC Faculty Affairs office.

Please consult USC's official documents or contact the relevant office for specific guidance.

This is typically initiated by your academic department and involves filling out a standard form, obtaining necessary approvals, and submitting to the graduate school or registrar's office. If you're unsure, consult with your department or the academic resources office for guidance!
gemini: You'll need a curriculum change proposal if you want to make changes to a course or program listed in the USC Bulletin. These proposals require faculty approval.

claude: For changes to the USC Bulletin, you generally need a curriculum change proposal if you're altering degree requirements, adding/removing courses, or modifying program structures. Minor edits like typos may not require a proposal. Consult your department's curriculum committee or the Registrar's office for specific guidance.

question: How do I propose a course action?

4. Propose to Academic Affairs: Submit your proposal through the appropriate channels, such as a course development committee.
5. Prepare for feedback: Be open to suggestions and ready to revise your proposal.
6. Implementation: Once approved, work with stakeholders to bring the course to fruition.

For detailed procedures, consult the Office of Academic Affairs.

question: How do I propose a program action?
answer: Program actions include proposing new, modifications to, or terminating degree programs, minors, concentrations, and academic certificates. Visit the Academic Programs website and scroll to the section for the action you’d like to take. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/program-actions/index.php)
phi:
To propose a program action at the University of South Carolina (USC), follow these steps:

1. Identify key stakeholders: Determine who needs to be involved, such as relevant departments, faculty, or student organizations.

2. Research: Gather information about your proposal idea, similar programs, and potential challenges.

3. Develop a proposal document: Outline your idea, objectives, benefits, required resources, and a timeline.

4. Gather support: Obtain endorsements from team members, advisors, or supporters.

5. Submit the proposal: Present it to the appropriate contacts, such as your department head or program coordinator. You may also submit it through USC's program portal if available.

6. Attend to feedback: Be open to suggestions or modifications from those who review your proposal.

7. Follow-up: Keep in touch with decision-makers and remain involved to ensure progress toward implementation.

Remember, keeping your proposal concise (50 words or less) and focused is crucial for effective communication.
llama: To propose a program action at the University of South Carolina, start by identifying a program or initiative that aligns with the university's strategic plan. Develop a proposal that outlines the program's goals, objectives, budget, and expected outcomes. Submit the proposal to the appropriate program review committee or department administrator for review and approval.

question: If my program has multiple concentrations, will a change to the program affect all of the concentrations?
answer: Concentrations are specific areas of study within the major. Anything outside of a concentration is part of the base program. If the change is to the Carolina Core, College Requirements, Program Requirements, or Major requirements (outside of the concentration), then the change will affect all concentrations. If the change is within a specific concentration itself, then it will not affect other concentrations in the program.

question: What are critical courses on the major maps?
answer: Courses may be marked as critical if there is a deadline for completion or if they may cause a delay in graduation because they serve as a prerequisite in a series of courses, have prescribed sequencing, or have limited offerings. There is a description of why courses are critical for a particular program in the first program note on the back of each major map. Critical courses are explained with examples in the Major Maps Training Module . (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8iJrJTDzKCQ&feature=youtu.be)
phi:
At the University of South Carolina, critical courses for a major map-related course typically include:

1. Cartography 101: Introduction to Maps - covers basics, symbols, scales.
2. GIS 101: Principles of Geographic Information Systems - essential for digital mapping.
3. Map Analysis and Interpretation - understanding spatial relationships.
4. Field Surveying Methods - practical skills for accurate data collection.
5. Cartographic Design - principles of map-making for effective communication.

Ensure to check with your specific department for tailored course recommendations.
llama:
For many majors at the University of South Carolina, critical courses are those that provide a foundation in the subject area or meet accreditation requirements. Some examples include:

* Intro to Psychology for Psychology majors
* Calculus I for STEM majors
* English composition for Humanities majors
* Introduction to Business for Business Administration majors

Please note that specific critical courses may vary depending on the major and department. Check the major map or consult with an advisor for more detailed information.

question: What are major maps?
answer: A major map is a layout of required courses in a given program of study, including critical courses and suggested course sequence to ensure a clear path to graduation. Major maps include universal terminology, a standard program of study, and a common 8-semester template. Access the Major Map Repository Learn more about major maps with the Major Map Training Module (/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/advisor_toolbox/majormaps.php, /about/offices_and_divisions/advising/advisor_training/training-index.php)

If you're looking for specific maps or navigation tools, the USC Campus Services or IT department can provide helpful resources.

question: What are the requirements for a cross-listed course?
answer: “A cross-listed course is a course that is offered under more than one course subject and is not appropriate for courses with the same course subject. Once a cross-listed course is approved, the courses are viewed as equivalent and identical and should ideally be able to be taken interchangeably within degree programs which require the course.” (ACAF 2.03) Cross-listed courses must have the exact same criteria as listed below: Course Number (if possible; at minimum the course numbers for the cross-listed courses must have be at the same level, i.e., lower division, upper division, mixed, graduate) Title Course Description Pre-requisites and Co-requisites Catalog Restrictions (e.g., by student level or program) Carolina Core or GLD designations (if applicable) Grade Mode (i.e., letter grade or pass/fail) Schedule Type (e.g., lecture, lab, seminar) a. Cross-listed courses may have different course delivery and location.
phi:
At the University of South Carolina, cross-listed courses typically follow standard university guidelines. Requirements may vary, but generally, you should:

1. Check both department listings for prerequisites.
2. Ensure credit limits are not exceeded if enrolling in multiple times.
3. Consult with your academic advisor for specific guidance.

For the most accurate and current information, please refer to USC's official academic catalog or student services portal.
llama: At the University of South Carolina, cross-listed courses are ones that are offered through multiple departments or schools. To take a cross-listed course, you need to meet the prerequisites for the course as specified by the department offering the course. Typically, you'll need to check the course catalog or consult with your academic advisor to confirm the requirements.
gemini: Cross-listed courses at USC often have different prerequisites depending on the department. It's best to check the course syllabus or contact the instructors for specific requirements.
mixtral: Cross-listed courses share similar content and requirements. You'll enroll under one course title, but it'll count towards both. Requirements are set by the specific department; check their syllabus or website for details.
claude: At USC, cross-listed courses are offered by multiple departments. Students can only receive credit for the course once, regardless of which department they enroll through. Requirements may vary, but generally, students must meet prerequisites for at least one of the listed departments.
gpt: A cross-listed course at USC is offered under multiple departments or programs but counts as the same course. Students must check specific prerequisites and departmental approvals, as requirements can vary. It's essential to consult the course catalog or academic advisor for precise details.

question: What are the requirements for a syllabus?
answer: All undergraduate and graduate courses must have a course syllabus that includes the following: Course title (including course subject designator and number) Instructor name and relevant contact information Final Exam day and time, as appropriate (from Office of the Registrar’s website) Class meeting days, times, and location, or equivalent Undergraduate or Graduate Bulletin course description Course learning outcomes Required text(s) and/or suggested readings, as appropriate Course requirements and grading Assignments, projects, quizzes, and/or exams with brief descriptions of expectations with points/weights assigned to each activity. Courses at the Mixed/Advanced Undergraduate/Entry Level Graduate Courses (500/600--level) must include separate grading schemes for undergraduate and graduate credit and one or more assignments for graduate credit that are clearly differentiated from undergraduate assignments Grading scheme and weights including what a student must do to receive a grade of A through F for a letter grade-based course, or an S or U, or a T or U, as appropriate for a non-letter grade course Topical outline of content to be covered, including a time allocation framework (e.g., week 1, week 2, etc. to include 14 weeks for a standard academic year course 6 session). The time allocation framework will be adjusted for other term lengths accordingly, consistent with course credit hours as defined in section III D. For Distributed Learning Courses, the syllabus is expected to articulate estimated time commitments of instructional time and course activity time consistent with course credit hours as defined above. The Committee on Instructional Development shall maintain and administer guidelines for such courses. Statement regarding academic integrity, honorable behavior and/or the Carolinian Creed (or excerpt thereof). Additional information may be found through the Office of Academic Integrity . Sample syllabi are also available through the Center for Teaching Excellence. Course attendance policy consistent with the expectations stated in the respective Academic Bulletin. Statement regarding disability services. Additional information may be found through the Student Disability Services Center and in policy STAF 6.02 Support Services and Accommodations for Students with Diagnosed Disabilities. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student_conduct_and_academic_integrity/, /about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/, /about/offices_and_divisions/student_disability_resource_center/for_faculty_and_staff/classroom_accessibility/index.php)
phi: A USC syllabus typically includes: course title, instructor's name, course description, learning objectives, grading criteria, assignment details, attendance policy, university's academic policies, class schedule, policies on late work, academic integrity, and contact information for the instructor. It's a comprehensive guide for understanding course expectations.
llama: According to the University of South Carolina's Policy on Course Syllabi, a syllabus must include: course title, course description, credit hours, meeting times, contact information for the instructor, course goals and objectives, assignments and evaluations, and any additional policies or expectations.
gemini: I can't give you specific syllabus requirements.  You should check with your professor or department for their guidelines.  They'll have the most accurate information!
mixtral: A USC syllabus typically includes course description, learning objectives, assignments, attendance policy, textbook info, and professor's contact details. Requirements may vary by faculty.
claude: At USC, syllabi typically include course information, instructor details, learning outcomes, required materials, grading policies, and a schedule of topics. Specific requirements may vary by department, but all syllabi should align with USC's academic policies and provide students with a clear course overview.
gpt: USC requires syllabi to include course objectives, a schedule of topics, grading policies, required materials, instructor contact information, and any specific policies regarding attendance and academic integrity. It's important for each syllabus to align with USC's academic guidelines and be clear to students.

question: What is a cognate?
answer: "A cognate is series of courses that display a distinct curricular pattern in one or more disciplines different from the major. Undergraduate cognates require a minimum of 12 credit hours in advanced level courses related to, but outside the major. Graduate cognates range between 9 and 18 credit hours. Cognates are variable according to what is appropriate as determined by the student and the major advisor. Thus, cognates are not subject to faculty governance review, and do not appear on either the transcripts or the diplomas." (ACAF 2.00)
phi: A cognate is a word that has a similar form and meaning in two languages because of a shared etymological origin. For example, the English word "mother" and the German "Mutter" are cognates, as both have evolved from the same Proto-Indo-European root. The University of South Carolina has diverse international students, creating an environment where understanding cognates can be quite beneficial for language learning.
llama: A cognate is an undergraduate student who enrolls in a separate related field, usually for one or two semesters, to explore a specific interest. USC offers cognates in various fields, such as business, engineering, languages, and more. This unique program allows students to earn a related minor or additional certification.
gemini: A cognate is a word that shares a common origin and similar meaning with a word in another language. For example, "father" in English and "padre" in Spanish are cognates.
mixtral: A cognate is a foreign language word roughly equivalent to an English one, often sharing similar meaning, spelling, or pronunciation. At USC, students can study cognates in various language programs.
claude: At USC, a cognate is a group of courses (usually 12-18 credit hours) in a specific area outside a student's major. It's designed to complement the major and provide broader knowledge. Cognates are required for most bachelor's degree programs at USC.
gpt: At USC, a cognate is a set of courses that students choose outside their major to complement their primary field of study, broadening their educational experience and providing interdisciplinary learning.

question: What is a concentration?
answer: "A Concentration is a series of courses that display a distinct curricular pattern within the major. They are often called options, emphases, tracks, areas, fields, or specializations. These are different from minors or cognates which are typically outside of the major. Concentrations are subject to faculty governance review, and appear on the transcripts but not the diplomas." (ACAF 2.00)

These allow students to focus on particular aspects or specializations, such as Finance within Business Administration, Environmental Biology within Biology, or American History within History. Choosing a concentration helps tailor your education to your interests and career goals.

question: What is an integrative course?
answer: An Integrative course is a course in the major, in which selected Carolina Core learning outcomes are integrated into the chosen major. Each undergraduate program must have an approved integrative course and require it as part of the major to ensure that all undergraduate students have had an integrative course in their major. It cannot just be an option in the major. Learn more on integrative courses . (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/academicpriorities/undergradstudies/carolinacore/courses/integrative-courses.php)
phi: An integrative course at the University of South Carolina (USC) is designed to combine multiple disciplines or academic fields, encouraging students to explore and connect concepts across traditional boundaries. This approach fosters a deeper understanding of complex issues and promotes critical thinking, creativity, and the ability to apply knowledge in diverse contexts. USC's integrative learning initiatives aim to enhance students' educational experiences by preparing them for the interdisciplinary nature of modern challenges.

question: What is Banner/Self-Service Carolina?
answer: Self-Service Carolina allows students, faculty, and advisors to access student information via the web. question: What is DegreeWorks?
answer: DegreeWorks is the University’s degree audit system. DegreeWorks aids both students and advisors in monitoring students’ progress toward degree and assist students in choosing the most appropriate courses to fulfill degree requirements. Integrated with students’ academic records in Banner, DegreeWorks matches student record data (courses, hours grades) with degree requirements categorically to identify which courses meet degree requirements and which courses need to be completed. Degree works also allows users to run “what if” and “look ahead” scenarios to both show how project courses will apply to a student’s major and apply a student’s course history to another program of study. ( Office of the University Registrar ) Learn more with the DegreeWorks Overview training module. (/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/toolbox/sysaccess/index.php, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=syUFK9gy56g&feature=youtu.be)
phi: DegreeWorks is a comprehensive digital learning platform at the University of South Carolina (USC). It tracks students' academic progress, ensuring they meet graduation requirements. DegreeWorks helps students plan their coursework, submit grades, and maintain academic standing. It's part of USC's commitment to facilitating student success and supporting academic advising.

It's like having a personal academic advisor – virtual and always up-to-date! Check it out to stay on top of your degree goals!

question: What is EAB Navigate?
answer: The EAB Advising Platform (known as Navigate on the Columbia campus), populated by a nightly feed of student data from Banner, provides a simple overview of key student information; success marker notifications; risk scoring for early intervention; a full transcript view and incoming student test and placement scores; easy list development based on hundreds of student attributes (GPA ranges; credit completion percentages; specific courses; participation in certain groups such as Honors, athletics, or sorority/fraternity; transfers; etc); a major matcher feature integrated with hiring and salary data provided by O-Net; easy referrals to support offices across campus who will reach out to the student and then close the loop with the advisor who made the referral. Learn more with the EAB Navigate Overview training module. question: What is included in progression requirements?
answer: Progression requirements should inform students and advisors of any deadlines and minimum performance standards to continue in a program. They may include deadlines for course or application completion, minimum GPA requirements, minimum grade requirements, minimum number of credits earned, etc. Learn more with the Progression Requirements training module. (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dkA00CaM6R0&feature=youtu.be)

2. Maintaining a minimum cumulative GPA of 2.0.
3. Fulfilling professional experience or internship requirements, usually 150 hours.
4. Seeking advising from a faculty advisor in your major field.
5. Undergoing academic probation review if necessary.

For detailed requirements, contact USC's specific program office.

question: What is the difference between prerequisites and restrictions?
answer: What is the difference between prerequisites and restrictions? Prerequisites are courses (successfully completed with a minimum grade of D, unless otherwise defined) that identify the skills and knowledge needed before enrollment in certain courses. Restrictions are conditions that limit the enrollment in certain courses to a select group of students. Restrictions may include: students of a certain academic standing students of a certain class standing (junior, senior, etc.) students admitted to a certain college, academic program, degree, minor, or certificate students belonging to a specific student group (Honors, Trio Scholars, etc.) students required to meet with an instructor, director, or obtain department permission. Note: Restrictions referring to students who have completed a specific number of credit hours and students with a certain minimum GPA cannot be enforced in Banner.
phi: Prerequisites are courses or skills required to enroll in a higher-level class, while restrictions often refer to limitations, such as GPA requirements or specific enrollment conditions that might prevent a student from registering for a certain course.
llama: Awesome question! At the University of South Carolina, prerequisites are courses that must be completed before taking a specific class. Restrictions, on the other hand, are rules that limit when or how often you can take a course due to factors like curriculum or availability. For example, a course might have a prerequisite of Intro to Psychology, while a restriction might limit you to taking it only during the summer session.
gemini: Prerequisites are courses you **must** take before enrolling in a specific course. Restrictions are limitations on who can enroll, like a major or class standing.
mixtral: Prerequisites are courses or requirements that must be completed before enrolling in a specific class. Restrictions refer to limitations on who can enroll, such as by major, class standing, or college.
claude: Prerequisites are courses you must complete before enrolling in a specific class. Restrictions are limitations on who can register for a course, often based on factors like major, class standing, or special permissions. Prerequisites focus on prior knowledge, while restrictions control enrollment eligibility.
gpt: Prerequisites are courses or requirements needed before enrolling in a specific class. Restrictions limit enrollment based on criteria like major, class standing, or department approval. Both ensure that students meet course expectations but cater to different aspects of eligibility.

question: When do cross-listed courses require additional proposals, and not just letters of concurrence?
answer: Common Reasons Proposals are Returned from the Curricula and Courses Committee: Anytime a course is being deleted. If multiple cross-listed courses are being deleted, separate proposals are needed. Anytime a new course is being created. If a new course is to be cross listed with another new course, two proposals are needed (one for each course). If a new course is going to be cross listed with an existing course, only one proposal is needed. The proposal that creates the new course can also create the cross list, but does need a letter of concurrency. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/docs/f23232.pdf)
phi: At the University of South Carolina, cross-listed courses may need additional proposals for approval if they span multiple departments or require inter-departmental coordination. This ensures a comprehensive curriculum alignment and resource allocation. Specific guidelines vary, so consult the Office of Undergraduate Studies or relevant department for exact procedures.
llama: According to the USC Office of Academic Programs, cross-listed courses that involve departments outside of the College of Arts and Sciences or the Darla Moore School of Business may require additional proposals, not just letters of concurrence. This typically applies to courses that require approval from the university's curriculum committee or other governing bodies.
gemini: I don't have specific information about when cross-listed courses require additional proposals. It's best to check the USC Registrar's website or contact the relevant department for the most up-to-date policies.
mixtral: At USC, cross-listed courses typically need only letters of concurrence. However, if course content or credit hours significantly differ, an additional proposal may be required, following the USC's academic policies and procedures. Consult the relevant committees for specific guidance.
claude: Cross-listed courses at USC typically require additional proposals when there are significant changes to the course content, requirements, or structure that affect multiple departments. Letters of concurrence are usually sufficient for minor changes or when adding a new cross-listing to an existing course.
gpt: Cross-listed courses at USC require additional proposals when significant changes impact learning outcomes or resource allocation. question: When is a syllabus required for a proposal?
answer: Common Reasons Proposals are Returned from the Curricula and Courses Committee: A syllabus should only be included in a proposal when necessary. When a syllabus is included, it will be reviewed by the Committee on Curricula and Courses. Proposals that require a syllabus: New course Significant change in the course description, and/or title When required by other committees (i.e., Carolina Core and Instructional Development -INDEV) Proposals that do not require a syllabus: Minor revisions to the course description or course title (e.g., slight rephrasing to replace terms as dictated by professional organizations often related to accreditation) Change in co-requisites or pre-requisites Change in course level, as long as not changing to/from 500 or 600. Change in Catalog Restrictions Change in Carolina Core or GLD designations Change in Grade Mode (not needed for removing pass/fail; needed if adding pass/fail) Change in Schedule Type (e.g., adding/changing lecture/lab/practicum format] Deleting a course (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/docs/f23232.pdf)
phi:
At the University of South Carolina, a syllabus is typically required for course proposals related to academic classes. If you're proposing a research project, workshop, or seminar, a detailed outline might be necessary. Please check with the specific department or organizing committee for precise guidelines. If uncertain, I recommend reaching out directly to the relevant office.

(Note: The user did not explicitly mention USC's context, so I addressed the general concept of syllabus requirements in an academic setting.)

question: When should I submit my proposal in order to be effective for the next Bulletin year?
answer: All proposals must reach the Committee on Curricula and Courses 10 days prior to the November meeting in order to make the December Faculty Senate cutoff for curriculum changes. It depends on the type of proposal submitted how long it will take to reach the Committee on Curricula and Courses and if there are any external approvals required. Program actions may take between 6 months and 2 years for full review (ACAF 2.00). Review the various levels of approval needed for various types of curricular actions. (/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/curriculum_services/approval_process/index.php)

question: Who can I contact in my college for assistance with curriculum actions?
answer: An Academic Program Liaison (APL) is designated for each college/school on the Columbia campus, for each comprehensive campus, and for the regional Palmetto College campuses. The APLs will serve as the main information resource on academic program actions and as the academic program liaison to the Provost’s Office for their respective units. The list of current Academic Program Liaisons can be found on the Planning and Assessment, Academic Program Liaison’s page of the Provost’s website. (/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/academic-program-liasons.php)

question: Why do Faculty need to know about DegreeWorks?
answer: Every undergraduate student has access to his/her personal degree audit. This in important because students monitor their own progress. Degree audits are especially important for athletes, veterans, and OSP (Opportunity Scholars Program) students, who must have an accurate degree audit for compliance (NCAA, GI Bill, Federal Funding). Faculty need to be aware of this because curricular decisions must be accurately reflected in DegreeWorks.
phi:
Faculty at the University of South Carolina (USC) need to know about DegreeWorks because it's an integrated technology system that tracks student progress toward degree completion. By understanding DegreeWorks, faculty can:

1. Monitor student coursework, ensuring timely completion.
2. Identify and address potential academic holdbacks or risks early.
3. Facilitate advising conversations to keep students on track.
4. Ensure accurate degree audits and certificate assessments.
5. Enhance academic success and graduation rates through informed interventions.

Knowledge of DegreeWorks supports USC's commitment to academic excellence and student achievement.
llama: Faculty need to know about DegreeWorks because it's a degree audit system that tracks student progress toward degree requirements. It helps faculty advisors ensure students are on track to graduate, identify potential issues, and make informed decisions about course recommendations. DegreeWorks is a helpful tool for faculty to support student success!
gemini: DegreeWorks helps faculty ensure students are on track to graduate! It allows them to view student progress, advise on course selection, and identify potential roadblocks.
mixtral: DegreeWorks is a valuable tool for USC faculty to track students' progress towards graduation, ensuring academic success. It provides up-to-date information on degree requirements, course history, and planned courses.
claude: Faculty at USC need to know about DegreeWorks because it's a crucial tool for academic advising. It helps track students' progress towards their degrees, allowing faculty to provide accurate guidance on course selection and graduation requirements. Understanding DegreeWorks enables faculty to better support student success.
gpt: Faculty need to know about DegreeWorks because it helps them advise students effectively on course selection, track academic progress, ensure students meet graduation requirements, and provide guidance on academic planning. It's an essential tool for supporting student success at USC.

question: Will my proposal require a letter of concurrence?
answer: Under ACAF 2.00: Interdisciplinary or Interprofessional Programs : Each instance in which an interdisciplinary or interprofessional program is created, revised, or terminated requires letters of concurrence from all related academic units. Dual, Joint and Other Collaborative Degree Programs: The proposal requires the approval of the faculty and leadership in both or all collaborating programs, and letters of concurrence from all university units in closely related disciplines. Under ACAF 2.03: Course Actions : If a course action has the potential to impact the curriculum offering of other units or campuses, then the proponent is responsible for procuring concurrence from such units or campuses. Cross-listed course: If one course is new, and the other already exists, the unit introducing the new course shall include a statement of concurrence from the unit with the existing course. If all courses in a cross-listing are existing courses, one of the units shall submit the course action, indicating all other courses with which the course is cross-listed. All other units shall provide to the initiating unit statements of concurrence, indicating all other courses with which the initiated course is cross-listed. Common Reasons Proposals are Returned from the Curricula and Courses Committee: Pre-/Co-Requisites : Changes to Pre-/Co-requisites (either their addition or removal) require a letter of concurrence for the department offering the pre-/co-requisite course unless the impacted courses are in the same department as the subject course. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/docs/f23232.pdf)

Usually, whether a proposal at the University of South Carolina (USC) requires a letter of concurrence depends on its nature and relevance to university guidelines and policies. For accurate advice, please reach out to the relevant department or your supervisor at USC. They can provide detailed guidance based on your proposal.

question: Will my proposal require any external approvals?
answer: Only programs require external approvals (the President, Board of Trustees (BoT), SACS, and CHE notification or approval), as outline in ACAF 2.00: "All new academic programs and program name changes across the entire USC system must be approved by the president. All new academic programs and program name changes across the entire USC system must be approved by the University Board of Trustees." CHE approval is required in the following cases: New degree programs; New academic certificates of any length in a new CIP code; New academic certificates of more than 18 credit hours in a current CIP code; Program revisions of more than 18 credit hours including the addition of one or more program concentrations and CIP code changes; Program revisions of delivery location to off-campus (50% or more of credit hours); Extension of an approved health professions program to additional sites in-state, and Center and institute proposals requesting new or additional state funding. CHE notification is required in the following cases: Program revisions of 18 credit hours or less (undergraduate) or 12 credit hours or less (graduate), including the addition of a single program concentration; New academic certificates of 18 credit hours or less in a current CIP code; Consolidation of concentrations within an existing program; Program name changes; Program four-letter designator changes; Program terminations; Program revisions of delivery method to distance education delivery (50% or more of credit hours); and Center or institute proposals in which state funding is not required. SACSCOC approval is required six months before implementation in the following cases: New programs, including new dual or joint degree programs; Program revisions that increase program length by 10%; New academic certificates of any length in any CIP code; Program terminations; Program revisions of delivery location to off-campus (50% or more of credit hours); and Program revisions of delivery method to distance education delivery (50% or more of credit hours) SACSCOC notification is required six months before implementation in the following cases: Program revisions of delivery location to off-campus (25% to 49% of credit hours); Program name changes. The program percentages must be based on the total number of credits required to earn the degree, not on the number of required credits in the major, minor or course, or the number of contact hours. SACSCOC may also request more information or additional materials such as a prospectus for any action.
